Chapter 10: Advanced Consequential Loss Insurance

Introduction

This chapter explores advanced features of consequential loss insurance, emphasizing add-on covers, rating structures, and policy conditions. It also delves into specific clauses, extensions, and detailed claim procedures.

A. Policy Features

1. Definition of Consequential Loss Insurance

  • Protects against financial losses due to business interruptions following physical damage.
  • Covers gross profit, standing charges, and increased cost of working.

2. Indemnity Period

  • Selected based on operational recovery time post-damage.
  • Policy rates vary depending on the indemnity period length.

3. Add-On Covers

  • Include professional fees, auditor's charges, and lay-off compensation.
  • Extensions for property at other locations, supplier’s premises, and customer’s premises.

B. Basis of Loss Assessment

1. Turnover and Gross Profit

  • Turnover: Revenue generated from goods and services.
  • Gross Profit: Net profit plus insured standing charges.
  • Policies define these components clearly to calculate claims.

2. Output Basis Specification

  • Measures loss based on production output instead of turnover.
  • Ideal for manufacturing industries.

3. Adjustments for Trends

  • Trend adjustments account for growth, new operations, or market conditions.
  • Special circumstances such as major events are considered.

4. Dual Basis Wages Insurance

  • Separates fixed and variable wage costs for accurate indemnity.
  • Provides flexibility during business recovery phases.

C. Policy Clauses and Conditions

1. Material Damage Proviso

  • Claims are payable only if a valid fire policy covers physical damage.
  • Ensures policyholder compliance with fire insurance coverage.

2. New Business Clause

  • Applies when a business has no historical turnover data.
  • Uses estimated figures for claims computation.

3. Exclusions

  • Costs not directly resulting from business interruptions, such as goodwill loss.
  • Penalties and non-operational losses are excluded.

4. Revenue Policies

  • Cover businesses where revenue generation is the primary concern.
  • Examples: Event management firms or professional service providers.

D. Claims Handling

1. Claim Process

  • Insured must notify the insurer promptly after an incident.
  • Provide supporting documents like trading accounts and auditor reports.

2. Role of Surveyors

  • Surveyors assess the extent of interruption and validate claims.
  • Preliminary reports highlight immediate observations.
  • Final reports detail the loss calculations and recommendations.

3. Trends and Variations Clause

  • Adjustments account for market or operational trends.
  • Ensures equitable indemnity calculation.

Conclusion

Chapter 10 covers advanced aspects of consequential loss insurance, highlighting the importance of accurate assessments, add-on coverage, and trend adjustments. Proper claim handling ensures businesses receive fair compensation for interruptions.
